Ms. María Justina F. works in the preparation of tortillas to sell to her customers in the Mayoreo Market in the city of Managua. She is a very dedicated person who, based on her sales, has been able to improve her standard of living. Now she hopes that Ceprodel will approve her loan to buy corn to continue in her business and thus improve herself and benefit her family who depend on her.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa B. is 45 years old. She is widowed and has given birth to three children, one son and two daughters. She says one of her children has completed school and is currently learning a trade. The rest are in the senior high school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. 
Adwoa is a trader. She trades in earthenware and all kinds of household items such as coal pots, brooms, etc. She procures the wares and the other items from wholesalers in Oda. Adwoa sells in a kiosk in the community market. She has been in business for eight years and desires to expand her business. She wants a loan to procure more goods to increase her stock. Adwoa hopes to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Sonia Elizabeth

texts.es: Sonia Elizabeth M. V. vive en Santa Tecla departamento La libertad, Sonia es madre soltera de 3 hijos que viven con ella, el ser madre soltera no es fácil para esta mujer es por ello que trabaja todo el día para que a sus hijos nunca les falte nada, esta madre ejemplar y muestra de lucha y trabajo, se dedica a la elaboración de pupusas y tortillas todos los días, también posee un pequeño inventario de venta de bebidas todo esto dentro de su misma casa, ahora Sonia solicita un crédito para poder adquirir más bebidas y así aumentar su inventario de productos que le ayudaran a obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Sonia Elizabeth M. V. lives in Santa Tecla in the department of La Libertad. Sonia is a single mother of 3 children that live with her. Being a single mother is not easy for this woman. For this reason, she works all day so that her children never lack anything. This exemplary mother and model of fighting and working dedicates herself to making maize dumplings and tortillas every day. She also has a small inventory of drinks to sell inside of her own home. Now Sonia is asking for a loan to buy more drinks and in this way, expand her inventory of products that help her to obtain greater earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more drinks to expand her business

loans.name: Nidia María

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora Nidia A. con mucho entusiasmo se dedica a atender su negocio de venta de alimentos los que son preparados por ella misma en su localidad. Se ha destacado por ser una excelente cocinera que a todos les agrada la manera en que prepara los alimentos.

Hoy en día ella ha acudido a Ceprodel con la necesidad de ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de los ingredientes de la comida y por eso espera confiadamente en que su crédito será otorgado satisfactoriamente para salir adelante.
texts.en:
In the city of Chinandega, Nidia A. tends her business of selling the food that she prepares. She stands out for being an excellent cook, and the way she prepares food pleases everyone. She comes to Ceprodel because she needs a loan to buy ingredients for the meals she makes. She hopes and trusts that her loan will be approved in order for her to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients for her meals

loans.name: Hirma

texts.es: Hirma tiene 37 años, es viuda, vive en casa alquilada con sus 3 hijos de 17, 15 y 7 años de edad. Desde hace 8 años se dedica a la venta de frutas de acuerdo a la temporada. Dotada de un triciclo para el transporte de su mercadería, todos los días por las mañanas se establece en una de las esquinas de la calle principal de su ciudad, además no sólo vende frutas, sino que también prepara jugos. Por el momento realiza este trabajo sola, pero cuando sus hijos están de vacaciones la apoyan con las ventas. Gracias a este negocio Hirma puede seguir sosteniendo la economía de su hogar, ya que las ganancias son rentables. Para un futuro cercano desea tener un local para evitar moviéndose de su lugar cada vez que los policías municipales se lo ordenan porque no cuenta con una licencia. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella es considerada una integrante muy colaboradora y responsable en su banco comunal y su parte, se compromete a seguir cultivando esta actitud positiva. El dinero que está solicitando será invertido en la compra de frutas al por mayor, las comprará en otra ciudad donde le venden a precios más bajos, por lo que tiene que costear no sólo la inversión en al compra de la mercadería, sino también el transporte.
texts.en:
Hirma is 37 years old, widowed, and lives in a rented house with her 3 children (ages 17, 15, and 7). For 8 years she has been in the business of selling seasonal fruits. Equipped with a tricycle, she transports her goods each morning to her vending location at one of the main street corners in the city. In addition to fruit, she also prepares juices for sale. She usually works alone, but her children help with the business during the holidays. Thanks to the profits she has earned, Hirma is able to maintain her household. In the future, she hopes to have a stable vending location because the municipal police order her to move because she does not have a license.

This is her third loan with MFP. Hirma is considered an integral and very responsible communal bank member, always encouraging a positive attitude within her group. The money she is requesting will be used to buy fruit wholesale in another city where prices are lower. In addition, the loan will be used to cover the cost of transporting her goods.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruit wholesale

loans.name: Malyn

texts.en:
Malyn E. owns and operates a variety retail store selling products in her community. Malyn is separated from her spouse and has school-aged children. She is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro City. Malyn is just starting her business.

In 2008, Malyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Malyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Malyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be her fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: 035-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
"Đạo N. Thị (44) is a 60-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Đạo is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 035-Quảng Hưng (18.01.035).

Đạo is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Đạo operates a family member's business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling pork products in the local community. Đạo has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2.100.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, Đạo joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Đạo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 8th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Đạo plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. Đỗ Thị Lân (41) is a 50-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, running a food stall.

2. N. Thị Lài (42) is a 33-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, making and selling food. 3. T. Thị Thuý (43) is a 25-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

4. Lê Thị Lý (45) is a 28-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

5. N. Thị Hân (47) is a 45-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Đạo N. Thị (44) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Đạo là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 035-Quảng Hưng (18.01.035).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ T.t heo trong cộng đồng địa phương. Đạo thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Đạo kiếm được khoảng 2.100.000 VND. Vào 2004, Đạo đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Đạo đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 8th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. Đỗ Thị Lân (41) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.

2. N. Thị Lài (42) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

3. T. Thị Thuý (43) là 25 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

4. Lê Thị Lý (45) là 28 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

5. N. Thị Hân (47) là 45 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding their businesses

loans.name: Oluwatoyin

texts.en: Oluwatoyin is 32 years old and married with five children. She sells motor spare parts and engine oil. She is requesting a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more motor spare parts and engine oil to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional motor spare parts and engine oil to sell

loans.name: Shah Tours Group

texts.en:
Modesta is a membe of the Shah tours borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro, She is 40 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 21, 20, 15, 10 years old. She also cares for other 4 dependents.

Modesta has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 15 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 40,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is  Modesta`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Modesta hopes to save more money and  expand her business.

Salome is another member of the same borrower group, she also requested the loan amount 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more  clothes

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon resides in the village of Punit, Benito Soliven, Isabela. Her husband works as a laborer and they have four children. Their eldest is Christian, eight years old; Jericho, seven years old; John Carl, two years old and Princess Joy, seven months old. They have a happy family despite their poor living conditions. She and her husband join hands to provide the needs of their children.

Corazon has a small pigpen at the back of their house and she started raising hogs early this year. This business is quite good because she considers it as an investment that she can use in times of emergency and to support the needs of their children.  She is requesting the amount of PHP4,000 to maintain her hog-raising business and somehow improve it. To generate income everyday, she also offers manicure and pedicure services to everyone in the village who is interested in paying her service fee of PHP40/person only. This gives her a daily income that is helpful in meeting her family daily needs.

loans.use: To maintain and improve her hog-raising business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more timbers

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Being a mother, 54-year-old Letecia T. is concerned about the lives her married children, her husband and their 22-year-old child who lives with and is dependent on her. Most of her children have unstable sources of income and are still under the umbrella of poverty.

To improve her living conditions, she recently joined a KIVA field partner in the Philippines, ASHI, to be able to access a loan which will enable her to start her business. Through this loan she plans to start up her own hog (pig raising) business. The profits she will earn from selling the hogs after four months of fattening would augment her husband’s income as a farmer. As the business grows, she would be able to support more of her children and grandchildren’s needs.  By then, her role being a mother would be completed.

loans.use: To buy piglets for fattening and selling. Also, some portion will be used to purchase materials for building a pig pen.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie M. lives in the village of Nabantu-an 1, Brgy Balintawak, Escalante City Negros Occidental. She is 48 years old, and married to Roberto M. who works as a laborer in the Ceres bus terminal. They have 3 children who are between 5 and 19 years old. Tessie has accepted the reality that her husband’s income is just too small to sustain their family's growing needs. This is why she explored ways to help her husband by earning on her own, because she also dreamed that her children would be able to finish their college education, have gainful work and live a more comfortable life.

It was quite providential that a friend invited her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon, and with her husband's consent, she became a member in 1997 and she used her loans to start a general store. The business turned out to be a good investment for it had an immediate impact by lightening the burden of the household expenses from her husband's shoulders. When a new opportunity arose to buy and sell scrap materials (old metals, plastic, bottles, etc.), she jumped at the chance and it improved her business income even further. Now her business earns an average net income of PHP 2,400 per month.

In her previous loan, she borrowed the amount of PHP 12,000, which she used as additional working capital for her general store and scrap business. The loan was fully paid on time, maintaining her standing as a good member. Now she is borrowing for her 12th cycle loan the same amount of PHP 12,000 to be used as additional capital for her businesses. She plans to use the income from this venture for house repairs and as a start-up capital for a new business which she is presently exploring.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her businesses

loans.name: Idersaikhan

texts.en:
S. Idersaikhan is 35 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His oldest two sons attend a local secondary school and his youngest daughter is in kindergarten.

Idersaikhan operates a raw materials trading business in his town. He started selling raw materials in 2007 after trading consumer goods for the previous seven years. Idersaikhan has made quick progress with his raw materials business and has built a good reputation among both his customers and suppliers. His earnings have enabled him to purchase a car for his family, and today his working captial exceeds 4,000,000 tugrugs (~3000 USD).

Idersaikhan is very decent person who works hard to achieve his goals no matter how difficult they might be. He says, "My business goal is to supply quality products to the market." He is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~2500 USD) loan to purchase more raw materials to sell in his business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials

loans.name: Chikaodile

texts.en:
Chikaodile produces and sells cellophane at retail prices to her customers. She also has a machine that she uses to produce popcorn to sell. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. Chikaodile is 44 years old and has seven children. Her children are excelling in their school work.

She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more materials to produce more cellophane to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to produce more cellophane to sell

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en:
Iyabo is 36 years old. She is married and has two children, the eldest of whom is 10 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband is an engineer and he helps to support their family. She is a LAPO client.

Iyabo sells medicine at retail prices. Her customers are mostly residents and friends. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Sibia

texts.es:
Sibia tiene 29 años, vive en su casa propia junto a su padre Nicolás, de 64 años, su madre Adelaida, de 53 años, y sus hermanos; Elmer de 22 y Yosmi de 11 años, también tiene una pequeña hija de tan sólo 3 años.

Desde hace 9 años se dedica a la comercialización de prendas de vestir, calzado y productos de belleza. Sus hermanos menores suelen cuidar de la pequeña hija de Sibia mientras ella trabaja todo el día en una entidad pública.
Sibia siempre lleva a su lado una fotografía de su hija, la cual observa cada vez que siente que no tiene fuerzas para continuar, su pequeña se convierte en el motor que la impulsa para luchar y echar al olvido las malas experiencias. También dice que con la separación de su pareja aprendió a valorarse más como mujer y a independizarse sin miedo, y está logrando surgir porque su actividad comercial es bastante rentable y le permite cubrir las necesidades de su familia, además de ahorrar.
Para el futuro esta trabajadora mujer desea ampliar aún más su negocio, abastecerse con mercadería de moda  y comprar vitrinas donde exhibir sus prendas, porque considera que sería una buena estrategia de marketing.

Sin miedo ella supo asumir su papel de madre y padre para que su hija no sienta ningún vació y está muy agradecida con MFP, tanto así que esta es la quinta vez que solicita un crédito con la entidad, porque sabe que económicamente está creciendo junto a los integrantes de su banco comunal, con quienes les gusta trabajar porque está comprendido por mujeres luchadoras como ella. Con el dinero que solicita, tiene planeado comprar decenas de prendas de vestir y calzados, porque la mercadería que adquirirá prácticamente ya está vendida porque son sólo pedidos.
texts.en:
Sibia is 29 years old and lives at home with her parents Nicolas (age 64) and Adelaida (age 53), her two siblings Elmer (age 22) and Yosmi (age 11), and her three year old daughter.

For the past nine years, Sibia has been selling apparel, shoes, and beauty products. Her youngest sibling looks after her daughter while she is at her job working for a public company. Sibia always keeps a photograph of her daughter with her to look at whenever she feels that she does not have the strength to continue. Her daughter motivates her to continue fighting and forget about her past struggles. She says that after separating from her husband, she learned how to value herself more as a woman, become independent, and live without fear. Sibia has been able to succeed because her business is profitable enough for her to cover her family’s expenses and set aside some savings. In the future, she wants to expand her business, acquire more apparel to add to her inventory, and purchase display cabinets for showing off outfits. She thinks this will be a good marketing strategy.

Sibia fearlessly assumes her role as both mother and daughter so that her daughter does not feel like a part of her is missing. She is grateful to MFP because she and the other members of her Communal Bank have grown financially as a group. Sibia enjoys working with them because they understand her because they struggle just like she does. She is requesting her fifth loan from the Institution. With the money she will receive, Sibia plans to buy clothing and shoes by the dozen because her existing merchandise is already sold and she has outstanding orders.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Mrs. Roem Chhieng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Roem C. is 47 years old, and the mother of three children who are students at the local school.  Her husband, Mr. Yom Yeng, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She is the village bank president for a group of 12 people. They live in Chumrov village in Tekeo province and will be using this loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Roem C. is a silk weaver who wants to expand her business to support her family. Thus, she decided to ask a loan to buy more silks for weaving.

loans.use: To buy more silks for weaving

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing is married with six children and her husband moulds blocks to support the home. She sells groceries, bags clothes, bags and foodstuffs. With these combined businesses she hopes to meet the basic needs and necessities of her family.

She hopes to expand her business and improve her family’s standard of living by making more profits from her business. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries, food, clothes, shoes, and bags to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, food, clothes, shoes, and bags to sell.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 33 years old and is married with five children aged between 6 and 14. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with seven people. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Rosemary works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She is a tailor on Lubaga Road and buys clothing materials from Owino market and so she pays for transport costs to and from shopping. She doesn’t pay rent for her business as she works from her home. Before starting her sewing/tailoring business she was dealing in locally made cold drinks.

Rosemary sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale and works six days a week. She has been in her business for nine years and with MCDT for six years. She is servicing her thirteenth loan and working with the same group members.

Rosemary wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning fashion and design shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel C. is from the village of San Isidro,Don Jose Aguirre, Manukan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 22 years old. Maricel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Maricel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Maricel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Maricel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en: Kiden S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials. Kiden is 41 years old and is widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children’s school fees. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo R. is from the village of Olango. He is 40 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately $760 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 29,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be his 5th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en: Felilpa is a 54-year-old rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur.  She is married to Ricardo and they have five children. The eldest no longer lives with them. “My rice farm is doing quite well, by God’s grace”, shares Felipa.  She hopes to improve her harvest by working extra hard.  Felilpa applied for a loan of Php10, 000 from CEVI to buy farm fertilizers and other supplements.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Kamuyu Iii Group

texts.en:
In the photo are the four members of the “Kamuy III” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Wara K., pictured on the left. She was born in Makeni and is age forty; she is married to a farmer and they have five children: two in secondary school and three in primary school.

Wara has earned six years of experience in selling cooked rice with meat, fish and vegetables. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business; she will buy cooking ingredients like rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), fish, meats, etc., in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy more cooking ingredients in large quantity

loans.name: Asunta

texts.en:
Asunta C. makes a living selling earrings and necklaces at a local shop and has applied for a loan to buy more necklaces to sell to her customers.  She is 39 years old and married. Her husband is a driver and they have three children, all of whom are in school. With the extra income made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to build a small hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy necklaces to sell to her customers

loans.name: Zandra

texts.en:
Zandra L. is from the village of Port Area, Iligan City. She is 20 years old, single and has 1 very young child. Zandra owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily specialty products like chicken barbecue, in the local community. Zandra has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Zandra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Zandra is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Zandra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yrysbu's Group

texts.en: The economic situation and total unemployment has pushed many people to seek employment in the Russian Federation but, however promising employment opportunities in other countries might be, this journey in search of a job is an extremely risky undertaking and requires one to be very brave and careful. Yrysbu U. is the leader of this group. She has raised four children. Her eldest daughter is 35. When she realized that her own country had little to offer in her youth, she decided to try her chances in Russia. Now she is working in Russia as a saleswoman. Yrysbu’s middle son, who is 30, also made up his mind to work in Russia. He is working in a clothing factory. Her second son, 27, works as a security guard in the biggest Kyrgyzstan market. Her younger daughter got married and now she is a housewife. As for Yrysbu’s husband, he is an actor. He works in the Naryn theater. Yrysbu raises cattle. Her son and daughter help her look after the cattle, so this activity does not present significant difficulties for Yrysbu. Eight years ago, Yrysbu bought a cow and since then has been striving to increase her cattle population. Yrysbu needs a loan to purchase sheep. She plans to save her earnings to help her grandchildren in the future. Her dream is to buy each grandchild a flat and a car. Yrysbu’s partners: Gulnara A., 45, is the mother of three sons. Gulnara combines two jobs. Apart from a regular job, she also breeds cattle. Gulnara hopes to obtain this loan and buy three sheep. Jidekul T., 62, is retired. She keeps cows and sells milk. Jidekul needs this loan to buy one more cow to increase her income. Jypargul O., 33, has a son. She works in a small factory producing sausages. Jypargul hopes to obtain this loan to buy a calf, feed it and sell it. She will use the money earned to prepare her children for school. Aimkan A., 37, has two children. She works as an accountant and also raises cattle. Aimkan sells milk and thus has an extra source of income. Aimkan has applied for this loan to buy a calf for feeding. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep for breeding

loans.name: Joelita

texts.en: Joelita R. is a 39-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: fishing and a general store. She lives in Prk. Angas, Brgy. Casay, Dalaguete, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and general-store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 24,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Joelita is borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can add to her working capital. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Joelita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team. http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Additional capital and buying additional fishing matrerials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To make home improvements.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos S. is from the town of Banga. He is 47 years old. Carlos is single. To make a living, Carlos owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Carlos has been engaged in his business for over 15 years.

Carlos joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlos has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Carlos is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase sacks of fertilizer and other farm inputs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Sharafat

texts.en:
Sharafat A. is very hardworking woman. Sharafat is single and lives with her parents. She tries to make more money for the family by working hard each day. About 3 years ago, she decided to start raising and selling animals. She raises calves and later sells dairy products  according to her clients' demand at the markets.  Her monthly income is 150-250 AZN. She prepares the dairy products for the eating pleasure of the people in her area.

Since Sharafat hopes for a great future, she decided to expand her businesses with the purpose of improving her family's living conditions. For this purpose she applied for 800 AZN and will buy one additional milk cow.

loans.use: To purchase one calf

loans.name: Madona Group

texts.en:
Ndigwaku T. is in her early thirties and is married with two children. For the past two years, she has been running her own broiler farming business. She works daily between 6:30 am and 6 pm and makes a good monthly profit.

This will be Ndigwaku's 2nd loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loan to increase her chicken population, a loan which she has successfully repaid. With this loan, Ndigwaku aims to buy more chick feed as well as medecine. 

Ndigwaku will share this loan with her loan group 'Madona', which totals 20 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the photo, Ndigwaku is the tallest person in the back, wearing a head scarf.

loans.use: chicken feed and chicken medicine

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina I. sells 'banku' and maize. She is married and has no children. Her husband is a farmer. Amina sells 'banku' which she prepares by soaking corn in water and then milling it to prepare the 'banku'. She also dries some of the maize for sale. She will use the loan to buy more maize to expand her business. Amina will then use the profit she will get to increase her capital for her business.

loans.use: buy more maize to expand her business

loans.name: Mesalim

texts.en:
Mesalim is a single woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated her business of selling Khanga’s (African traditional cloth) for over five years. She sells door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby. Mesalim faces the major challenge of high transport costs as she has to move from door-to-door selling Khanga’s. She hopes to establish a Khanga shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase Khanga’s and also purchase construction materials for her shop. She decided to join Yehu because it is near her homestead and hence is accessible.

loans.use: To purchase Khanga's and construction materials for her shop.

loans.name: Altanhuu

texts.en:
Altanhuu A. is 42 years old and lives with his wife and four daughters in Han-Uul district of Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. The family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His younger daughter, age 10, attends a local secondary school and the youngest daughter is in kindergarten, while his wife cares for the family’s livestock herd.

Altanhuu is also a herder and operates a mobile dairy trading business that prepares and sells milk in the local community.  After many years of running his business Altanhuu has gained a reputation amongst his customers as a reliable supplier of milk.  He sells a high quality of milk and therefore his sales are very good.  Herding and raising livestock is a difficult job that requires a lot of persistence from the herder.  Altanhuu is a very clever and hardworking man and says, " Further, I would like to continue to herd our livestock and live well."  Altanhuu is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase hay in order to feed his livestock.

loans.use: To purchase hay to feed his livestock.

loans.name: Zepyur

texts.en:
Zepyur A. was born and spent her whole life near her extended family in the village of Meghrashen in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is married and has two children. Her daughter is 22 years old and her son is 24. 

Zepyur has a high school education. She has been a self-employed farmer for the past 15 years. Zepyur considers herself to be a hard-working, sincere person. She is pleased with microfinance loans because they can enable her to grow her business. She is looking for a loan to purchase additional cattle. With this investment Zepyur expects the family income to increase by 25 percent. 

In addition to supporting her family, she provides her relatives with agriculture products from the family farm. Some of the additional income from her business will be used for her son’s wedding.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Floreda

texts.en:
Floreda D. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 55 years old. Floreda is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Floreda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & snack foods in the local community. Floreda has been engaged in her business for a year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Floreda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Floreda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Floreda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products like snack foods and biscuits. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Floreda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products like snack foods and biscuits

loans.name: Juana Marina

texts.es:
doña Juana Marina C. tiene 51 años de edad, esta casada y es madre de dos hijos.
su esposo se dedica al negocio del transporte y Juana se dedica a la venta de ropa nueva y calzado.
viven en el Barrio San Jose de la ciudad de San Lorenzo.
su negocio lo abre de lunes a domingo, tiene una empleada que le ayuda a atender los clientes.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de blusas, pantalones y zapatos.
desea tener su negocio bien surtido para la epoca de navidad.
texts.en:
Juana Marina C. is 51 years old, she is married and mother of two children. Her husband works in the transport business and Juana sells new clothing and footware. They live in the San Jose neighbourhood of the city of San Lorenzo. 

She opens her business from Monday to Friday, and she has one employee who helps her serve the customers. She will use this loan for the purchase of blouses, pants, and shoes. She would like to have her business well stocked for the Christmas season.

loans.use: Purchase of ladies, men's and children's clothing

loans.name: Thacienne

texts.en: Thacienne is 35 years old, married and has two children. Currently, her children both attend school. Thacienne sells a variety of household goods in her boutique, which she has been operating for six years. Her husband is a businessperson. Thacienne will use the loan to purchase more items for her boutique. With the new profits from her expanded boutique, Thacienne plans to build a business premises. She would like to have a successful and wealthy business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more items for sale

loans.name: Cerila

texts.en:
Cerila M. is from the village of Sampagar, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Cerila is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Cerila owns & operates a business raising livestock.  The main source of income for the business comes from buying and raising pigs for sale. Cerila has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Cerila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cerila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. 

Cerila is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Cerila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 34 years old, married and has one child.

In 2007, Haidar decided to open his own business to improve his family's quality of life, so he opened a food market. He is well known and has an excellent reputation in his local area.

He is requesting a $3,000 loan to renovate his shop and buy two refrigerators. He is planning to expand and develop his business in the future.

loans.use: To renovate his shop and buy two refrigerators

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Dried fish vending is the main business activity for Mrs. Fe R..  She is 30 years of age, single and is a resident of P1 Labo, Ozamiz City. 

To find ways to support her family, Fe R. decided to engage in dried fish vending. She started this business in 2008 with a little capital. Now, she is earning an average net income of not less than P6,000.00.  With a good credit record, she is given the privilege of applying for her first loan cycle in the amount of P30,000 to use as working capital for her existing dried fish business and for her rice farm. She wishes for more progress on her business and good health to her family.

loans.use: Working capital for dried fish business and for rice farming

loans.name: Darlina

texts.en:
Darlina is a rice farmer living in the town of Aurora, Agusan Del Sur with her family. She cultivates her land to plant and harvest rice crops. Darlina does her best to keep her crops healthy. She also wants to be able to sell the best kind of rice in her town. She works hard to sustain her family and have her own savings.

Darlina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Darlina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Darlina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Julio Alberto

texts.es:
Julio de 31 años de edad, reside en San Miguel, está soltero y es empleado de una gasolinera, trabaja hace 2 años como despachador, cubre sus gastos y ayuda en el hogar con su salario.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para cubrir unos gastos personales, sobre una escritura, ya que no dispone de la cantidad que el notario cobra por realizar los trámites de traspaso a nombre de él.
Le ayudara esta inversión a tener más patrimonios e ir mejorando su condición, también tener su propia casa.
texts.en:
Julio, 31, lives in San Miguel.  He’s single and employed at a gas station.  He’s worked there as a Gas Pump Attendant for two years.  He covers his expenses and helps at home with his salary.

He is asking for a loan to pay for some personal expenses related to a deed because he lacks the amount that the notary charges to process a change of ownership to him.

This investment will help him have more assets and improve his condition as well as to have a house of his own.

loans.use: to pay notary fees

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy S. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Cristy is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Cristy owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, biscuits,  shampoo, soap & breads in the local community. She also sells electronic loads for several cell phone networks from SMART and GLOBE. Cristy has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Cristy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and fund working capital for her business. 

Cristy is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods to sell. This loan will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase additional canned goods and snack foods to sell

loans.name: Thaer

texts.en:
Thaer, a young man from Tulkarem city, works in a chocolate factory on the production line in Tulkarem, Thaer took out a loan from FATEN to help his brother and contribute to his wedding expenses that his brother couldn't cover himself.

Thaer receives a good salary that will help him repay the loan to FATEN easily. Thaer appears in the picture above.

loans.use: to pay part of his brother's wedding expenses.

loans.name: Anitha

texts.en:
Anitha is 36 years old and is married, with three children between the ages 12 and 22 years old as well as three other dependent relatives. Anitha has been running a pub for the past 5 years. This business is well organized. She employs 11 people to help her. Anitha works from 6am until 10pm every day.

Anitha has requested her first loan from Vision Finance Company, s.a, in order to expand her business by buying more beer, like Primus, wisque, mitsing and so on. With an expansion, Anitha hopes to increase her profits. With this increase, she will be able to buy her own house, create a Hotel, and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more beer for her pub, such as riquer, wisque, and so on.

loans.name: Dona

texts.es:
La Sra.  Dona pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de la Inmaculada” del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Está casada, tiene 57 años y tiene tres hijos; todos ya cuentan con familia propia.

Inicia su pequeño  negocio de venta de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad  con un capital de S/200.00 nuevos soles; haciéndose muy rápidamente de muy buena clientela por su carisma y buena atención,  lo que le permitió ampliar su negocio.
 
Con este préstamo de S/. 1 500.00, comprará  y surtirá con mas  productos su negocio, comprará racimos de plátanos, sacos de azúcar, arroz, paquetes de fideos, jabas de huevos así como insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes y otros productos para dar una buena atención a sus clientes.


Dona es una mujer emprendedora,  su sueño es contar con un Mini Market está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella, a realizar sus sueños.
texts.en:
Dona is a member of the ‘Virgen de la Inmaculada’ Communal Bank, located in the District of Tarapoto within the Province and Department of San Martín. She is 57 years old, married, and has three children who all have their own family now.

She started her small business selling groceries and basic needs items with 200 Peruvian Nuevos Soles (PEN) in capital. She created a very good customer base quickly due to her charisma and good service, thus allowing her to expand her business.

With this loan of 1,500 Peruvian Nuevos Soles (PEN), she will purchase more products for her business such as bunches of bananas, sacks of sugar, rice, packages of pasta, crates of eggs, as well as supplies for personal hygiene and household cleaning, packs of soda and other products in order to provide good service to her customers.

Dona is an enterprising woman and her dream is to have a mini-market. She is very grateful to Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women like her to fulfill their dreams.

loans.use: to buy bunches of bananas, sacks of sugar, rice, packages of pasta, crates of eggs, personal hygiene and household cleaning supplies, packs of soda and other products.
